abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is rated marginally
            satisfactory, while project sustainability is likely. World
            Bank performance is rated unsatisfactory overall.
            Specifically Bank supervision was unsatisfactory: Frequent
            turnover of Bank staff handicapped continuity in
            supervision, with six task team leaders over the life of the
            project and frequent turnover of other supervision staff.
            Insufficient time in the field by supervision staff was
            another characteristic until late in the project, in part as
            a result of the very difficult travel conditions in the
            project area. Year-to-year variation in Bank supervision
            budgets was also a factor during much of the period, and at
            times no IDA staff were available to participate in field
            visits, which were then conducted by the Swiss Agency for
            Development Cooperation (SDC) alone. Overall performance was
            initially quite weak (especially in financial management,
            procurement, afforestation efforts, and social forestry
            implementation) but steadily improved during the course of
            the project, during the last few years operational
            performance improved significantly, most notably at the
            level of the project facilitation office, which has
            developed a critical mass of technical and site management
            skills which represent the core achievement of the project.
            This also represents the major element of the project's
            positive achievements with regard to sustainability and the
            potential for wide replication of the methodology
            demonstrated during the project. On this basis overall
            borrower performance is rated Satisfactory, though other
            aspects of borrower performance had significant
            shortcomings. Lessons learned for each project component
            involved: 1) lack of sector work; insufficient market/demand
            analysis; the need for cost-sharing among beneficiaries in
            infrastructure investments; and the consistent
            overestimation by preparation teams of forest production
            potential (forest management); and 2) too much time taken to
            reach consensus on social forestry policies; the necessity
            of developing a national grazing policy through a
            consultative process; resort to central government approval
            for community forests when decentralized approval is
            allowed; loss of credibility among local communities when
            the social forestry approach is not implemented in a timely
            manner; and when providing free seedlings, private nurseries
            may be inappropriate (social forestry); furthermore, 3) land
            for reforestation is often subject to other uses by local
            communities and therefore plantations have proven
            unsustainable in the absence of meaningful involvement of
            current users; 4) weak financial management skills should
            have been addressed up-front; institutional development
            specialists should have been included in the design team;
            training investments should be based upon a sound needs
            assessment, backed by a covenant to ensure compliance in the
            credit agreement; and all training is consistent with an
            established training program (subject to the project
            agreement). Finally, 5) co-financing should be co-determined
            for the project component(s); should provide a greater focus
            on shared "core concerns" and exclusion of
            "non-core" components (e.g.,
            afforestation/reforestation); and should increase
            effectiveness by providing a shorter project duration and
            concrete intermediate targets (with consequences for non-fulfillment).
